meta.title: The environmental benefits of car sharing

text: The Berkeley University study of Car2go members found between a four percent to 18 percent reduction in GHG emissions across their study population, with an average of 10 percent. Some car sharing companies have gone further still, and have options for their members to offset the CO2 emissions associated with their vehicle usage by investing in climate protection projects that reduce atmospheric CO2 levels. Looking again at the Car2go study, researchers found that the estimated 28,000 or more vehicles that car sharing took off the road reduced parking demand in the cities.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: The environmental benefits of car sharing

text: Some car sharing companies have gone further still, and have options for their members to offset the CO2 emissions associated with their vehicle usage by investing in climate protection projects that reduce atmospheric CO2 levels. Looking again at the Car2go study, researchers found that the estimated 28,000 or more vehicles that car sharing took off the road reduced parking demand in the cities. Because car sharing results in fewer cars on the roads, this means that over time there will be the potential to reclaim land that was previously dedicated to parking, and less need to build new parking infrastructure.
label: car_sharing

text: Looking again at the Car2go study, researchers found that the estimated 28,000 or more vehicles that car sharing took off the road reduced parking demand in the cities. Conclusion
In conclusion we have seen that the sustainability model for the urban car sharing platform produces some additional goals for the RE content model. In this case we found the additional goals “low maintenance susceptibility” and “vehicle independent integration”. The resulting activities provide an additional layer of depth to the RE content model, by illustrating the composition of the goals according to their sustainability features.

Car Sharing Systems as a Sustainable Transport Policy: A Case Study from Lisbon, Portugal
Sustainable Urban Transport
ISBN: 978-1-78441-616-4, eISBN: 978-1-78441-615-7
ISSN: 2044-9941
Publication date: 13 May 2015
Abstract
Originality/value
Overall, the results obtained from this research work quantify the contribution of car sharing to sustainable transport and highlights the positive effects of promoting a technological shift. These facts reinforce the need for public policies to support the integration of car sharing within the city’s solutions to promote a more sustainable mobility.

Abstract
Originality/value
Overall, the results obtained from this research work quantify the contribution of car sharing to sustainable transport and highlights the positive effects of promoting a technological shift. These facts reinforce the need for public policies to support the integration of car sharing within the city’s solutions to promote a more sustainable mobility. The successful deployment of car sharing systems can be influenced by policies targeting features such as allocation of parking, the fees and complementarity with public transport, signage and markings, and marketing of social and environmental benefits.

text:
'Sustainable Transportation' brings carpooling alternatives to W&M
The program, labeled as Sustainable Transportation, is part of a three-year effort by students, faculty and staff of the College to map out student commuting patterns and to better provide transportation services for students in a sustainable, environmentally friendly fashion. Max Cunningham ’13, who received a grant from William & Mary’s Committee on Sustainability to complete the project, worked this past summer in conjunction with faculty advisor John Swaddle, Parking Services Director Bill Horatio and Director of Auxiliary Services Carolyn Davis to research and enhance the carpooling program.
label: car_sharing

'Sustainable Transportation' brings carpooling alternatives to W&M
The program, labeled as Sustainable Transportation, is part of a three-year effort by students, faculty and staff of the College to map out student commuting patterns and to better provide transportation services for students in a sustainable, environmentally friendly fashion. Max Cunningham ’13, who received a grant from William & Mary’s Committee on Sustainability to complete the project, worked this past summer in conjunction with faculty advisor John Swaddle, Parking Services Director Bill Horatio and Director of Auxiliary Services Carolyn Davis to research and enhance the carpooling program. A 2009 survey of College commuting patterns found that students were interested in actively carpooling, but many were still commuting to school alone each day.

A 2009 survey of College commuting patterns found that students were interested in actively carpooling, but many were still commuting to school alone each day. “My advisor and I thought that if we could just increase communication between people interested in carpooling, we would see more of ridesharing on campus.” Cunningham said.

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text:
Tips for setting up a car-pool
Just like screening potential flatmates, you need to consider what factors are important to your carpool. Here are some general tips for contacting potential car-pool partners and setting up your carpool:
- Get comfortable. Talk on the phone or arrange to meet beforehand somewhere to interview the potential carpool partners – bring a friend along for company if you’d like.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text:
Here are some general tips for contacting potential car-pool partners and setting up your carpool:
- Get comfortable. Talk on the phone or arrange to meet beforehand somewhere to interview the potential carpool partners – bring a friend along for company if you’d like. - Agree on the little things: smoking/non-smoking, food and drinks okay or not, radio on or off (and what stations); raise any other personal annoyances (eg, use of mobile phones, passengers reading/doing paperwork).
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: Talk on the phone or arrange to meet beforehand somewhere to interview the potential carpool partners – bring a friend along for company if you’d like. - Agree on the little things: smoking/non-smoking, food and drinks okay or not, radio on or off (and what stations); raise any other personal annoyances (eg, use of mobile phones, passengers reading/doing paperwork). - Decide who will drive or what days each of you will drive if sharing driving responsibility.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: - Decide who will drive or what days each of you will drive if sharing driving responsibility. - When will you meet: set a timeframe and decide what to do if people are late. - Where will you meet: arrange drop-off and pick-up points at home or wherever is comfortable (if you don’t want your carpool knowing your home address, use a nearby corner for your pick-up).
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: - When will you meet: set a timeframe and decide what to do if people are late. - Where will you meet: arrange drop-off and pick-up points at home or wherever is comfortable (if you don’t want your carpool knowing your home address, use a nearby corner for your pick-up). - Cost: if driving isn’t equally shared, decide how petrol and parking costs will be shared.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: - Where will you meet: arrange drop-off and pick-up points at home or wherever is comfortable (if you don’t want your carpool knowing your home address, use a nearby corner for your pick-up). - Cost: if driving isn’t equally shared, decide how petrol and parking costs will be shared. - Decide how to deal with the unpredictable: for example, illness, over-sleeping, mechanical problems.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: - Decide how to deal with the unpredictable: for example, illness, over-sleeping, mechanical problems. Decide ahead of time how to handle such situations. Decide who is notified if someone is ill, and establish how each carpool member wants to be contacted in such emergencies (eg, work, home or cell-phone number, or email).
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

If one of your carpool partners makes a carpool late, agree early on how long drivers should wait at each stop.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: Decide who is notified if someone is ill, and establish how each carpool member wants to be contacted in such emergencies (eg, work, home or cell-phone number, or email). If one of your carpool partners makes a carpool late, agree early on how long drivers should wait at each stop. Have a back-up plan for yourself if your carpool ride must leave without you (leaving you either at home or on campus).

Have a back-up plan for yourself if your carpool ride must leave without you (leaving you either at home or on campus). Once you have formed your carpool group, here are some general tips for the smooth running of the carpool
- Be on time, whether driving or being picked up.

text:
Have a back-up plan for yourself if your carpool ride must leave without you (leaving you either at home or on campus). Once you have formed your carpool group, here are some general tips for the smooth running of the carpool
- Be on time, whether driving or being picked up. If you can't make it, call in PLENTY of time for others in the carpool to make other arrangements.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text:
Once you have formed your carpool group, here are some general tips for the smooth running of the carpool
- Be on time, whether driving or being picked up. If you can't make it, call in PLENTY of time for others in the carpool to make other arrangements. - If you are driving, make sure you have plenty of fuel in the tank and that your car is running well and is clean.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: If you can't make it, call in PLENTY of time for others in the carpool to make other arrangements. - If you are driving, make sure you have plenty of fuel in the tank and that your car is running well and is clean. No one wants extra stops on the way.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Carpooling tips and FAQs

text: If you can't make it, call in PLENTY of time for others in the carpool to make other arrangements. - If you are driving, make sure you have plenty of fuel in the tank and that your car is running well and is clean. No one wants extra stops on the way.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Benefits of Carpooling

text:
Carpooling offers many benefits
Carpooling will save YOU money
Carpooling allows you to share the cost of gas and parking, cutting your expenses by nearly 50% or more; the more occupants in your carpool the more you save. Not only will you be saving, but you will also help reduce the costs we all pay towards the construction of new roads, road maintenance and air pollution related health costs.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Benefits of Carpooling

text:
Carpooling offers many benefits
Carpooling will save YOU money
Carpooling allows you to share the cost of gas and parking, cutting your expenses by nearly 50% or more; the more occupants in your carpool the more you save. Not only will you be saving, but you will also help reduce the costs we all pay towards the construction of new roads, road maintenance and air pollution related health costs. Carpooling is better for the environment
Having fewer cars on the road means reduced Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and improved air quality.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Benefits of Carpooling

text:
Carpooling is better for the environment
Having fewer cars on the road means reduced Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and improved air quality. It’s good for your health
According to Environment Canada, air pollution caused by vehicular travel is linked to a number of health concerns including respiratory diseases, cardiovascular disease, allergies and neurological effects. By carpooling, you help reduce these health risks for yourself and everyone else.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Benefits of Carpooling

text:
It’s good for your health
According to Environment Canada, air pollution caused by vehicular travel is linked to a number of health concerns including respiratory diseases, cardiovascular disease, allergies and neurological effects. By carpooling, you help reduce these health risks for yourself and everyone else. Research also suggests that carpooling is less stressful than commuting alone.
label: car_sharing

text:
By carpooling, you help reduce these health risks for yourself and everyone else. Research also suggests that carpooling is less stressful than commuting alone. Carpooling is convenient
Carpooling provides commuting convenience comparable to driving alone, with less stress and with the added bonus of companionship while you’re commuting.

meta.title: Benefits of Carpooling

text:
Carpooling offers many benefits
Carpooling will save YOU money
Carpooling allows you to share the cost of gas and parking, cutting your expenses by nearly 50% or more; the more occupants in your carpool the more you save. Not only will you be saving, but you will also help reduce the costs we all pay towards the construction of new roads, road maintenance and air pollution related health costs.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Benefits of Carpooling

text:
Carpooling offers many benefits
Carpooling will save YOU money
Carpooling allows you to share the cost of gas and parking, cutting your expenses by nearly 50% or more; the more occupants in your carpool the more you save. Not only will you be saving, but you will also help reduce the costs we all pay towards the construction of new roads, road maintenance and air pollution related health costs. Carpooling is better for the environment
Having fewer cars on the road means reduced Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and improved air quality.
label: car_sharing

text:
Research also suggests that carpooling is less stressful than commuting alone. Carpooling is convenient

meta.title: Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool

text:
Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool
Most mornings, at 6:30 am, Smryna resident Jansen Donsbach meets her sister-in-law, living in Murfreesboro, and they take turns driving one another to their jobs in Nashville on a shared, hour-long commute. Donsbach works at the Tennessee State Capitol downtown as a legislative assistant and her sister-in-law works at a health care business on West End Avenue.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool

text:
Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool
Most mornings, at 6:30 am, Smryna resident Jansen Donsbach meets her sister-in-law, living in Murfreesboro, and they take turns driving one another to their jobs in Nashville on a shared, hour-long commute. Donsbach works at the Tennessee State Capitol downtown as a legislative assistant and her sister-in-law works at a health care business on West End Avenue. By carpooling 1,300 miles this year, Donsbach has earned $80 in three months through a local corporate partnership meant to encourage transportation alternatives.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool

text: Without the payments, "I don't know that I would think about doing it as much." Through Hytch, an app created by local entrepreneur and business leader Mark Cleveland, area businesses pay Middle Tennessee commuters as much as 12 cents a mile to carpool. Nissan alone pays 5 cents per mile, and other local businesses, including HG Hill Realty, Onin Staffing, Franklin Synergy Bank and Lipscomb University contribute to carpooling employees or those carpooling from certain areas of Middle Tennessee, Cleveland said.

text: Through Hytch, an app created by local entrepreneur and business leader Mark Cleveland, area businesses pay Middle Tennessee commuters as much as 12 cents a mile to carpool. Nissan alone pays 5 cents per mile, and other local businesses, including HG Hill Realty, Onin Staffing, Franklin Synergy Bank and Lipscomb University contribute to carpooling employees or those carpooling from certain areas of Middle Tennessee, Cleveland said. The carpooling incentives come as Nashville debates a $5.4 billion transit plan, which many area businesses have endorsed.

text: More than 1.1 million passengers used MTA services through the employer-backed fares last year. The Transportation Demand Management program is encouraging businesses to take advantage of the Internal Revenue Service's option to exclude up to $260 a month from an employee's income as a pre-tax income. Instead, they should consider subsidizing public transportation or carpooling or encouraging bicycle use through secured parking and shower facilities, Clements said.

text: More than 30 area businesses cover the cost of public transit for employees or offer reduced fares, according to Miranda Clements, who leads Nashville's new Transportation Demand Management program. The program is part of a nationwide program to encourage alternative transportation and is funded through a Tennessee Department of Transportation grant and an MTA match. More than 1.1 million passengers used MTA services through the employer-backed fares last year.
label: car_sharing

The Transportation Demand Management program is encouraging businesses to take advantage of the Internal Revenue Service's option to exclude up to $260 a month from an employee's income as a pre-tax income. Instead, they should consider subsidizing public transportation or carpooling or encouraging bicycle use through secured parking and shower facilities, Clements said.
label: car_sharing

meta.title: Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool

text: The Transportation Demand Management program is encouraging businesses to take advantage of the Internal Revenue Service's option to exclude up to $260 a month from an employee's income as a pre-tax income. Instead, they should consider subsidizing public transportation or carpooling or encouraging bicycle use through secured parking and shower facilities, Clements said. "Businesses are increasingly taking advantage of such programs due to benefits such as reduced parking demand, recruitment and retention of talent who desire a transit, walkable and bicycle friendly lifestyle, recognition in the community as an environmentally responsible company and cost savings due to a healthier and more productive workforce," Clements said.

Transit incentives popular in other metros
Wendy Duren, a program director at Arlington Transportation Partners in Virginia, said the pre-tax transit benefit is the most effective transportation benefit that can be offered to DC commuters.

meta.title: Businesses offer transit, carpooling incentives as recruitment, sustainability tool

text: The companies pay a reduced rate to the city and the perk is often used as a recruitment tool, according to Seattle transportation officials. "It doesn’t matter where you are on the income spectrum, people are incentivized by free stuff," said Jonathan Hopkins, who leads a government-funded nonprofit Commute Seattle that partners with Seattle, King County, Sound Transit and Downtown Seattle Association. Ralph Schulz, CEO of the Nashville Area Chamber of Commerce that has endorsed the transit plan, said Nashville businesses have adopted a range of incentives, including reimbursing Uber and Lyft rides, to enhance quality of life and lower stress for employees.

text: "It doesn’t matter where you are on the income spectrum, people are incentivized by free stuff," said Jonathan Hopkins, who leads a government-funded nonprofit Commute Seattle that partners with Seattle, King County, Sound Transit and Downtown Seattle Association. Ralph Schulz, CEO of the Nashville Area Chamber of Commerce that has endorsed the transit plan, said Nashville businesses have adopted a range of incentives, including reimbursing Uber and Lyft rides, to enhance quality of life and lower stress for employees. "We encourage businesses to incent ridership, stagger times," Schulz said.

"We encourage businesses to incent ridership, stagger times," Schulz said. "When you are growing as fast as we are, no one transit solution takes care of the whole issue."

The push to carpool
Hytch has tallied more than 850,000 shared miles this year, 65,000 carpooled trips and more than 1 million vehicle miles not driven as a result of carpooling, Cleveland said. Most Hytch carpools consist of two passengers, but more than 1,500 rides have included seven or more passengers. Commuters have earned more than $31,000 since February when Hytch launched its incentives model.

text: Hugh Thomas, a managing partner at Onin Staffing firm which has three Nashville-area offices, said his company is rolling out Hytch incentives to boost retention in a competitive job environment and to make commutes more appealing. "As wonderful as their mission is to alleviate the traffic problem, my motivation is to get employees to work," Thomas said. Nissan partnered with Hytch because carpooling aligned with its global initiative focused on intelligent mobility, said Nissan spokesman Chris Keeffe.

text:
These tips will set you up for success. Talk logistics
Most people find that conversations about logistics are critical to the success of their new commute. If you’re carpool or vanpooling, do you have any flexibility with departure times?

text:
Talk logistics
Most people find that conversations about logistics are critical to the success of their new commute. If you’re carpool or vanpooling, do you have any flexibility with departure times? Will you and your ridesharing partners share the cost of gas?

text:
Sustainable Transportation at the U of S
The university’s commitments to sustainability include a goal to increase the quality and use of sustainable mobility options (public transit, carpooling, cycling and walking) for travel to, from and within the campus. The table below show the current modes of transportation chosen for commuting.
